comments.commentBody: I am generally pleased by the tone of the comments posted here. What I have heard and read elsewhere is very sad. Given Mr. St. Hubert's history of violence, including against his mother, and a history of mental health, one finds it hard to believe that the discharging psychiatrist, who conducted an evaluation, did not make any recommendations for psychiatric treatment. Yes, Mr. St. Hubert demonstrated some improvement, but this may have been primarily due to the structure within the penitentiary system and the well-integrated psychiatric and psychological services. It is unbelievable that the professionals who evaluated him upon discharge would have concluded that this individual was not going to relapse into behavioral problems. One hopes the investigators can examine the clinical notes from the discharge plan and assess any risk evaluated by the clinical staff and recommendations for post-release functioning as a "normal" citizen. If this is not documented in the chart, it did not happen, and these professionals need to be confronted about it. If this indeed happen, was this risk assessment communicated to anyone in the community? If so, where did it fall through the cracks? It would also be naive to think that leaving it all up to Mr. St. Hubert, i.e., to follow up with medication compliance and possibly psychotherapy/counseling, would really happen. The evil unleashed and tragedy that followed clearly show that there was a major breakdown in the "system."

Oh jeez... the post about the "good old days".  As other commenters stated, pregnancy in the past was no less stressful, but people were taking a different attitude of "whatever will be, will be", because there was not much that could have been done in a case of a bad outcome.  Not so much today.  We expect a perfect outcome with every pregnancy, and are genuinely shocked when that doesn't happen and something bad occurs.  Odds are that yes, everything will be just fine, but it is certainly not every pregnancy's outcome.  I am personally very grateful for all the testing that's available, but I understand that no one can guarantee anything in life.  Refusing testing is a valid option, however, people really need to understand more about tests and statistics than they do (and majority of people really have trouble understanding the difference between different tests and their risks - it's obvious even from reading these comments how generally poorly informed people are).  In a good OB practice, a genetic counselor can walk a patient through different testing options depending on what their preference is.  Knowledge is power IMHO.

I was the sports editor of San Diego State's student newspaper in 1967-68, when Don Coryell was the coach. It was the year after John Madden left the school for the Oakland Raiders. I loved college sports for decades.

Over the past year I've changed my mind--to the point that I don't follow college sports any more. In the state in which I live, California, three of the five highest paid state employees are college coaches. Nick Saban, Alabama's coach, makes more money every five days than my wife, a university English professor, makes in a whole year. The students who play college athletics line the pockets of their schools--and of the NCAA's administrators--but receive virtually nothing.

Watching those athletes be used by greedy fatcats is little different than complicity.
